title: How to make my blog post better - Quora

response.answer_text: Today, good enough simply isn’t. Not when millions of posts are published daily. Not when today’s average post is 1,054 words; requiring anywhere from three hours to an entire day to write. Yikes! Ain’t nobody got time for that. But, you still need the results, and you still want that powerful post that comes once in a blue moon. Here’s the problem: Likely, your information is great, facts all check out. BUT: it’s boring, it’s not compelling enough to get people to sit up and take notice. Here’s a few ways to grab the reader by the horns and truly connect them to the piece: Tip#1: Include a compelling ‘hook’ The pretentious-sounding “lede” in a good article is what gets people to take the bait. A compelling narrative, fact, stat or fable at the beginning that literally hooks people into reading your post. Anecdotes Jon Morrow of CopyBlogger does this better than almost anyone. I find myself weeping like a little baby after reading his content: On Dying, Mothers, and Fighting for Your Ideas.  Reading the introduction of this piece feels like a story. It’s about the doctor telling his mother about his condition, one that he’ll be facing his entire life, bound to a wheelchair. Ingeniously, he builds incredible suspense, adding awkward pauses and intriguing dialogue before finally tying it back to the topic of the piece. As a result, you get lost in story, you get literally hooked into reading. It becomes a battle to stop reading and you can’t close out now. Start on the Opposite Side of Where The Post Ends In this example above, Jon also delivers on this approach to writing his crafty hook. It starts in a vastly different place from where it ends. Misdirection becomes the norm. You expect one thing, only to discover the exact opposite, smashing any expectations you had, keeping you interested. Sometimes that could mean striking unlikely comparisons between two subjects, like Professional Chefs + Sales. The point: Misdirection catches the reader off guard, nearly forcing them to keep reading, and eventually, sharing your content. Lean On Your Angle What’s an angle? Isn’t that just my post topic? Let’s get this defined, since it’s of utmost importance. Topic = what you’re writing about Angle = what side you’re picking / how you convey the current topic of discussion Good? Good. Here’s an example: This post: 5 Reasons No One’s Reading Your Blog Posts. The topic is about blog post mistakes. It’s about why people aren’t sharing your content, and why they aren’t sticking around for more than the first paragraph. BUT, the angle is about how YOU can’t afford to be making these errors. Based on stats, evidence and proven examples, the angle hooks you in to care about what it says because there are consequences if you don’t. ———————————————————————————————————————— You can check out the other 4 tips/reasons why people aren’t reading or sharing your post (and how to fix them) here: 5 Reasons No One’s Reading Your Blog Posts
